page.title: 05Black Dyke Mills
page.content: The oldest part of the mill was built in 1832 by John Foster. It is still owned by his descendants, some of whom work there. Originally about 200 people worked there. Now 729 are employed on many different shifts: about 50% live in Queensbury. The mill produces about 400 pieces of cloth, of various lengths, per week. They produce (flannel, mohair, wool and (worsted:) 80% of this is exported. They import most of their raw materials, the most important of which is goat hair from Turkey and South Africa. After many processes it is woven into (the finest mohair in the world.) It is famous throughout the world and especially popular in Japan. Many people come to Queensbury to buy direct from the (Black Dyke Mill Shop.
